body:
Hi @niketanpansare , please find this [link](https://www.sfu.ca/~ssurjano/stybtang.html). Here, I am implementing this type of functions.

![s-tang-fun](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20439730/32066652-21703808-ba9e-11e7-9293-89379c8d9391.PNG)

For example, we have a neural network or an optimization algorithm. So,
1. we take one function (say  Styblinski-Tang function), (first fig. from left )  
2. we give input & output values of this function to the network(2 & 3 fig. from left are the networks trained on regular batching & sobolev kind of training after 20 trains), to see how well our function is being approximated (here, sobolev network approximated styblinski-Tang to a reasonable accuracy).
3. These functions are necessary to check all the nuts & bolts of the network are sound enough.

![fun-description](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20439730/32066396-3e8b4cee-ba9d-11e7-965c-2d6b42e7fde7.PNG)

1. You can consider running following Python code to get y and x:
```python
from systemml import MLContext, dml, dmlFromResource, dmlFromFile, dmlFromUrl
ml = MLContext(spark)
s = """ 
source("./many_local_minima.dml") as fn;
a = 20.0; b = 0.2; c = 2 * 3.1415
d = ??
x = rand(rows=1, cols=d)
y = fn::Ackley(x, a, b, c)
"""
script = dml(s).output('x', 'y')
res = ml.execute(script)
xMat, yMAt = res.get('x', 'y')
x = xMat.toNumpy()
y = yMat.toNumpy()
```

2. Then you can plot them using the code mentioned in https://matplotlib.org/examples/mplot3d/subplot3d_demo.html

3. Paste the generated plots in the PR (and may be with expected plots) to show that the functions are working correctly :)

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/2208/

this is very nice - but please leave `nn/layers/dropout.dml` as it is - this can very easily be done automatically. After IPA, constant folding and branch removal this function already boils down to a single statement - the only reason why it makes a difference right is that inlining happens before IPA. I'll add another IPA pass that inlines such single statement functions.

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/2209/

Hi @dusenberrymw , 
Sorry, I haven't seen your above comment before.
please find the development the PR [here ](https://github.com/j143/systemml/pull/2/files).  Can you review there, thanks.
LGTM - thanks @dhutchis. I'll merge it in because there might be other special cases but I think your HopDagValidator did its job here and revealed a hidden bug - I'll create a fix for it.

@j143 It looks like there was a forced update to the master branch last night that wiped out the half of month worth of commits, which are now showing up in this PR.  Don't worry about it, as soon as the master branch is fixed, this PR will look fine again.
This looks fine. What sizes have you tested this out with?

I think you might also need to change the `.sh` files in the [perftest directory](https://github.com/apache/systemml/tree/master/scripts/perftest) (like : [genDescriptiveStatisticsData.sh](https://github.com/apache/systemml/blob/master/scripts/perftest/genDescriptiveStatisticsData.sh)).
For the 0.15 release, @asurve used the `.sh` scripts. I am not sure if he still wants them to be valid, but lets try to keep both scripts working unless we have to retire the `.sh` scripts.
@nakul02 good catch. I make these changes soon.

Thank you @asurve for updating the release document. I viewed new content as web page under `bundle exec jekyll serve`. Please make some minor formatting corrections to the new markdown file. For example, `
` tokens can be removed.
thanks @gweidner Updated changes.
LGTM - I will merge PR and push `gh-pages`.

Great, LGTM üëç 
Then you can merge. Ping me later and I'll show you how.
Thanks @gweidner
ping @bertholdreinwald @prithvirajsen :)

While I don‚Äôt see any particular reason to merge the two (you are making control of the extra statistics less fine grained üòÄ), if you really wanted to, I can suggest that internally, you can let the GPUStatistics.DISPLAY_STATISTICS and LibMatrixDNN.DISPLAY_STATISTICS remain and set both of them true when your newly introduced parameter ‚ÄúFINEGRAINED_STATISTICS‚Äù is true. That way if one wanted to go back to more fine grained control of these fine grained statistics, it would be possible.

The reason is usability and forcing developers not to add additional flags.

The user has to know only one flag: fine grained stats. All others are dev flags n should not be exposed. This avoids permutations such as finegrained but not gpu stats n so on.

 The dev has to decide if the stats has to be exposed and if yes, she has only two options: stats or finegrained stats. 

For the above reasons, I would prefer to remove gpu stats n DNN stats completely to avoid technical debt. If it has to be enabled in future, the person HAS to do that extra work.
And I would prefer to add this before 1.0 as this is an API feature

There are two sets of people here - developers and users. 

If the task is to make it easier for users, what I suggested might be enough and you can have a single user facing system setting and the internals can expose two different sets of global variables. 


If the task is to make it so that developers need not add an extra global variable for another set of fine grained statistics, then unifying all internal fine grained statistics is fine by me. 

# begin of 2 cents. 
Please note that if we go this route, we will forgo the ability to control which part of the system collects fine grained stats and it will be an all or nothing. If for future experiments, we wish to turn off fine grained stats for a particular subsystem while focusing on another, it will not be possible with this approach. 
#end of 2 cents

I agree, not collecting statistics from custom components is a conscious decision. If it were to be revisited, then it has to be addressed more wholistically. According to me, GPU statistics is just fine grained stats when SystemML ends up using gpu. Similarly for DNN operations.
Alright, since this PR takes into account the discussion we had above, LGTM :+1:
Seems like an important patch. LGTM üëç
Thanks @nakul02  ... I will merge :+1:

Hi @mboehm7 , this implementation is to take care of only simple `xor(op1, op2)` operation. 
BTW, how only to run this test `src/test/java/org/apache/sysml/test/integration/functions/binary/scalar/XorTest.java`, w/o `mvn verify`.
great - I'll have a look tomorrow. In the meantime, you can simply run your test or individual subtests via junit in your IDE.
gentle ping @asurve.

tested with `spark-submit target/SystemML.jar -f scripts/xor_test.dml` (please, remove this file in commit!)
```
xor of 1, 1 is 0
xor of 1, 0 is 1
xor of 0, 1 is 1
xor of 0, 0 is 0
SystemML Statistics:
Total execution time:           0.001 sec.
Number of executed Spark inst:  0.
```
I will try to add the bool string, matrix ones later on. Thanks.
LGTM - thanks @j143. FYI: while merging, I brought a modified version of your tests back in and did some minor cleanups.

Thanks.

Hi @mboehm7 , in last part of log file above, `NonSymmetricMatrixException` has been thrown. , the matrix for which we are computing the `cholesky` factorization is a **positive definite**.

- May be at some intermediate calculation, the _matrix nature_ is changing which might be causing the problems. And, the size I have used for testing the large matrices - `2500x2500`.

Thanks. & Merry christmas üíê

sure I'll finish it up and then merge it later today.

ok just to explain what was missing - here is what I changed:
* rewrote the test to compare against R and test AND, OR, XOR, NOT (the expected matrix computation was actually wrong)
* fixed the runtime operations (the implementations did not correctly convert doubles to boolean and implemented OR as AND)
* fixed missing compiler integration for AND, OR, and NOT (compiled always scalar outputs)
* fixed missing runtime integration into MR and SPARK instructions
* removed new instructions and redirected AND, OR, and XOR to arithmetic instructions which otherwise would be an exact duplicate.

The integration of NOT is a bit trickier and will follow tomorrow.
thanks again for the initial version @j143 - I'll merge
with #714 this is already working (I still have to do some cleanups to nicely integrate NOT) but maybe you can use this PR to add further tests for scalar-matrix, matrix-scalar combinations.

yes that's a good idea. For all bitwise operations, we should explicitly cast all inputs to integer, which is in line with R semantics (from the R docs: "numeric vectors are coerced to integer vectors"). Please use {{UtilFunctions.toLong(x)}} for safe casts which avoids anomalies if an integer cannot be represented exactly in double.

1) I would recommend to do the cast in the individual function objects' execute methods `public double execute(double in1, double in2)` - that way you can leave the scalar instruction as is, and it will work for both scalars and matrices with the exact semantics of R.

2) You can simply run your test as a junit test inside your IDE. If you get errors that Rscript cannot be found, you need to put the path of the bin directory of your R installation into the global PATH variable (OS env variable).
